newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL shares down at noon, small-cap issues dominate.
newsitem.headline: KL shares down at noon, small-cap issues dominate.

text.p: Malaysian stocks were weaker at midday on Monday as small-capitalised issues dominated trading activity and institutional investors remained largely sidelined.
At the midday break, the benchmark Composite Index slipped 1.30 points, or 0.12 percent, to 1,068.76. The small-capitalised Second Board index lost 1.13 points to 564.82
"It's the end of the month and some funds are closing their books," said Faez Khairuddin, head of research at SJ Securities.
Construction company Chase Perdana was the morning's most active stock, gaining 80 cents to 22.80 ringgit.

Chase said on Friday it plans to diversify into stockbroking with the acquisition of a substatntial stake in Sabah-based brokerage house for 22 million ringgit. Sabah state is located on the island of Borneo.
Infrastructure developer Intria Bhd shed 14 cents to 3.96 ringgit after announcing plans to redevelop two prominent sports stadiums in central Kuala Lumpur.

"Although the new projects secured is positive, it also indicates that Intria won't be making a direct bid for New Straits Times' Commerce Asset stake. We are still maintaining a 'hold' on Intria," said brokers Thong & Kay Hian in a report.
